text:
I began my podcast from zero last year. My plan was to invite guests who I could leverage their audiences.

Simple but effective. I got a sponsor who covered all associated costs from one guest, two medium projects from one guest, and so far a year's worth of retainer work from another guest.

text:
I'm writing an article about the differences between hiring a *part time content marketer* and a *content marketing agency.* 

What would you say are the pros and cons of each one? At what stage should a company hire someone part time, or go for an agency?

(happy to add a quote and a link to your website in the article!)

part time content marketer
and a
content marketing agency.

What would you say are the pros and cons of each one? At what stage should a company hire someone part time, or go for an agency?

(happy to add a quote and a link to your website in the article!)

text:
I use Julian Shapiro's intro structure: 

• Establish shared context.
• Surface a problem and what's at stake.
• Explore the problem's significance.
• Tease a clever solution.
But earlier this month I came by  <@UJ3K7N8GJ>'s article on writing persuasive copy.  You can use his structure too to write intros. (couldn't find the link to the article,  but here's what I got from it)  

• Thesis- Present the status quo, the viewpoint that is currently accepted and widely held.
• Antithesis- Articulate the problems with the thesis.
• Synthesis-  Share a new viewpoint (a modified thesis) that resolves the problems.
They are both more or like the same. You state the normal, describe the problem with the current state and the impact it might have on readers then present a solution or a different perspective free of the problems.

Antithesis- Articulate the problems with the thesis.
Synthesis-  Share a new viewpoint (a modified thesis) that resolves the problems.

They are both more or like the same. You state the normal, describe the problem with the current state and the impact it might have on readers then present a solution or a different perspective free of the problems.

text:
I think one of the biggest value adds that an agency brings is reliability over time. You're going to pay a LOT more per hour for the same output with an agency, so you really need to understand what those value-adds are.

Reliability is big one since the agency (we'll assume it's a decent agency) has backup resources, more layers of QA, etc.

Another agency value-add is the Account Management and/or Project management layer. If the content needs are complex and/or you as a client have little time/patience/skill in communicating with creatives, an agency can be a huge help.

PT person can be much cheaper, but if they go MIA you can be left high and dry. A PT person is probably less invested in your success than a FT person and may deprioritize your needs more than an agency that wants to build a longer term relationship.

A PT person may also not be able to handle a certain level of complexity, and you have to communicate with them  directly.

elements.text:
I think one of the biggest value adds that an agency brings is reliability over time. You're going to pay a LOT more per hour for the same output with an agency, so you really need to understand what those value-adds are.

Reliability is big one since the agency (we'll assume it's a decent agency) has backup resources, more layers of QA, etc.

Another agency value-add is the Account Management and/or Project management layer. If the content needs are complex and/or you as a client have little time/patience/skill in communicating with creatives, an agency can be a huge help.

PT person can be much cheaper, but if they go MIA you can be left high and dry. A PT person is probably less invested in your success than a FT person and may deprioritize your needs more than an agency that wants to build a longer term relationship.

A PT person may also not be able to handle a certain level of complexity, and you have to communicate with them  directly.

text:
At the risk of oversimplifying, I think there are common tradeoffs that apply to "agency or freelancer" in general, specific agency focus notwithstanding.  For instance, freelancer pros include:
• Generally less expensive
• Generally willing to let you dictate terms/arrangement, rather than dictating it to you
• Can often be flipped to an FTE if the arrangement works well
• Not subject to agency bait-and-switches (sell you on people with lots of experience, then offer a 'blended' rate and staff your account with less experienced people)
Whereas agency pros include:
• Generally more reliable/more skin in the game
• Established commodity with more resources
• Saves backfill and recruitment costs
• Shields you from individual personnel drama (or tries to, anyway :laughing: )
• More likely to have expertise to help leadership at a strategic level

elements.text: At the risk of oversimplifying, I think there are common tradeoffs that apply to "agency or freelancer" in general, specific agency focus notwithstanding.  For instance, freelancer pros include:
Generally less expensive
Generally willing to let you dictate terms/arrangement, rather than dictating it to you
Can often be flipped to an FTE if the arrangement works well
Not subject to agency bait-and-switches (sell you on people with lots of experience, then offer a 'blended' rate and staff your account with less experienced people)
Whereas agency pros include:
Generally more reliable/more skin in the game
Established commodity with more resources
Saves backfill and recruitment costs
Shields you from individual personnel drama (or tries to, anyway
More likely to have expertise to help leadership at a strategic level

text:
I'll add: it's as important to vet your agency as it is a PT hire... maybe even moreso given the price tag. There are a LOT of scummy "agencies" out there that totally do the bait-n-switch per <@U017XD7H4P7>'s comment.

Or, "the agency" is really just a single charming salesperson who knows a few freelancers themselves. They collect a % for subcontracting these people out to you and add next to no value.

elements.text: I'll add: it's as important to vet your agency as it is a PT hire... maybe even moreso given the price tag. There are a LOT of scummy "agencies" out there that totally do the bait-n-switch per

's comment.

text: That's a great point.  There are less barriers than ever to a single person changing website copy from first-person singular to first-person plural and, viola!, instant 'agency'

elements.text: That's a great point.  There are less barriers than ever to a single person changing website copy from first-person singular to first-person plural and, viola!, instant 'agency'

text: (I should say, you gotta start somewhere when you're standing up an agency, and some clients have to be among your first.  But it's jarring on the client side, since there's a mental model of an agency, and it isn't "freelancer that got one too many gigs and took on a couple of subcontractors.")

elements.text: (I should say, you gotta start somewhere when you're standing up an agency, and some clients have to be among your first.  But it's jarring on the client side, since there's a mental model of an agency, and it isn't "freelancer that got one too many gigs and took on a couple of subcontractors.")

text:
Yeah! Running a teeny crew of a few subcontractors is totally legit, so long as you're transparent about that value-add.

Early-agency days, you can position as a boutique, compete on price, and go after smaller, leaner clients to whom you'll be 100% dedicated because their relatively modest budget is actually your biggest billings.

There is a grey area of scrappiness that deserves respect—those times when you punch above your weight and puff up your copy/offering to sound a league above what you are—and if you win, you grow immediately to fill that vacuum. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text:

There is a grey area of scrappiness that deserves respect—those times when you punch above your weight and puff up your copy/offering to sound a league above what you are—and if you win, you grow immediately to fill that vacuum.

text: It's a legitimate shortcut, but I don't dig how they try to pass it off as a replacement for an actual Content Marketer. Like all other business trends, the hype will come and go, then people will come to their senses and actually use it in a sensible manner.
